actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned pursuant to a previous special order. The next meeting is scheduled for 11:00 a.m. on December 11, 2025.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Schweikert moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.

actions-list.header: NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO OFFER RESOLUTION
actions-list.actionItem: Mr. Green (TX) notified the House of his intent to offer a privileged resolution pursuant to clause 2(a)(1) of rule IX. The Chair announced that a determination will be made at the time designated for consideration of the resolution.
Mrs. Kiggans (VA) asked unanimous consent that when the House adjourns today, it adjourn to meet at 11:00 a.m. on December 11. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 940 — "Electing a Member to certain standing committees of the House of Representatives."
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 3383 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mrs. Wagner moved that the committee rise.

At the conclusion of debate on the Waters amendment No. 5, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Waters demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Waters amendment No. 5.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Waters,  numbered 5 printed in Part B of House Report 119-399 to define and prohibit fees charged by SEC-registered individuals and entities that are not clearly disclosed or proportional to the services provided.
On agreeing to the Waters amendment; Failed by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Waters amendment No. 4.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Waters,  numbered 4 printed in Part B of House Report 119-399 to provide additional transparency and accountability for entities making exempt offerings under Regulation D via additional disclosure requirements on Form Ds.

At the conclusion of debate on the Waters amendment No. 3, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Waters demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Waters amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Waters,  numbered 3 printed in Part B of House Report 119-399 to require investment advisers and hedge funds to perform know-your-customer verification and implement anti-money laundering procedures for foreign clients.
On agreeing to the Self amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Self amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Self,  numbered 2 printed in Part B of House Report 119-399 to modify section 105 to clarify that the subsection may not be construed to authorize expenditures for additional full-time equivalent employees.

At the conclusion of debate on the Self amendment No. 1, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Mr. Self demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Self amendment No. 1.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Self,  numbered 1 printed in Part B of House Report 119-399 to strike section 307 relating to enhancing multi-class share disclosures.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 3383.
The Speaker designated the Honorable James C. Moylan to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 936 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, H.R. 3668 and S. 1071. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, and H.R. 3628 under a structured rule; and H.R. 3668 and S. 1071 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one motion to recommit on H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, and H.R. 3668; and one motion to commit on S. 1071.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 936. H.R. 3383 — "To amend the Investment Company Act of 1940 with respect to the authority of closed-end companies to invest in private funds."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 3638, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Pallone demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House adopted the amendments en gros as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 3638.
On agreeing to the Self amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Self amendment No. 5.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Self,  numbered 5 printed in Part C of House Report 119-399 to revise the required supply-chain assessment to evaluate barriers to expanding U.S. capacity to manufacture, deliver, and install components for generating or transmitting electricity, rather than only manufacturing.
On agreeing to the Min amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Min amendment No. 4.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Min,  numbered 4 printed in Part C of House Report 119-399 to expand the proposed study to assess opportunities to deploy advanced transmission technologies, including advanced conductors.
On agreeing to the McGuire amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the McGuire amendment No. 3.

An amendment, offered by Mr. McGuire,  numbered 3 printed in Part C of House Report 119-399 to include a new line about foreign entities of concern disrupting supply chains to undermine United States leadership in artificial intelligence development.
On agreeing to the Min amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Min amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Min,  numbered 2 printed in Part C of House Report 119-399 to require DOE to evaluate how veterans, transitioning servicemembers, and military spouses can support workforce needs in the electricity supply chain, including barriers they face and opportunities for improved federal coordination.
On agreeing to the Gosar amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Gosar amendment No. 1.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Gosar,  numbered 1 printed in Part C of House Report 119-399 to require the Secretary to report on any vulnerabilities due to the employment of noncitizens at facilities in the U.S. that generate or transmit electricity.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 3638.
The Speaker designated the Honorable James C. Moylan to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 936 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, H.R. 3668 and S. 1071. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, and H.R. 3628 under a structured rule; and H.R. 3668 and S. 1071 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one motion to recommit on H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, and H.R. 3668; and one motion to commit on S. 1071.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 936. H.R. 3638 — "To direct the Secretary of Energy to prepare periodic assessments and submit reports on the supply chain for the generation and transmission of electricity, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 3628, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Pallone demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
On agreeing to the Moore (WV) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
The previous question was ordered on the bill and the amendment pursuant to the rule.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 936, the House proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Moore (WV) amendment No. 1

An amendment, offered by Mr. Moore (WV),  numbered 1 printed in Part D of House Report 119-399 to require the GAO to conduct a review of existing IRP processes and whether states are considering reliable generation in their portfolios.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 3628.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, H.R. 3668 and S. 1071. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, and H.R. 3628 under a structured rule; and H.R. 3668 and S. 1071 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one motion to recommit on H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, and H.R. 3668; and one motion to commit on S. 1071.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 936. H.R. 3628 — "To amend the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 to add a standard related to State consideration of reliable generation, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 432, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Guthrie demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 432.

Considered from the Discharge Calendar. H. Res. 432 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2550) to nullify the Executive Order relating to Exclusions from Federal Labor-Management Relations Programs, and for other purposes."
Consideration initiated from the Discharge Calendar.

actions-list.header: On motion to discharge Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 222

actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to the rule, the House proceeded with 20 minutes of debate on the Golden (ME) motion to discharge.
Pursuant to clause 2 of Rule XV, Mr. Golden (ME) called up motion No. 3, to discharge the Committee on Rules from further consideration of H. Res. 432.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 312
On motion to commit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 209

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. S. 1071 — "To require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to disinter the remains of Fernando V. Cota from Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery, Texas, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on motion to commit S. 1071, and passage of the bill, if ordered.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of December 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on S. 1071, the Chair put the question on motion to commit and by voice vote announced the noes had prevailed. Mr. Norcross demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to commit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mr. Norcross moved to commit to the Committee on Armed Services.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on S. 1071.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, H.R. 3668 and S. 1071. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, and H.R. 3628 under a structured rule; and H.R. 3668 and S. 1071 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one motion to recommit on H.R. 3898, H.R. 3383, H.R. 3638, H.R. 3628, and H.R. 3668; and one motion to commit on S. 1071.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 936. S. 1071 — "To require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to disinter the remains of Fernando V. Cota from Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery, Texas, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 3857 — "To amend the Snow Water Supply Forecasting Program Authorization Act."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 215
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 216

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 936 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3898) to amend the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to make targeted reforms with respect to waters of the United States and other matters, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3383) to amend the Investment Company Act of 1940 with respect to the authority of closed-end companies to invest in private funds; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3638) to direct the Secretary of Energy to prepare periodic assessments and submit reports on the supply chain for the generation and transmission of electricity, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3628) to amend the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 to add a standard related to State consideration of reliable generation, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3668) to promote interagency coordination for reviewing certain authorizations under section 3 of the Natural Gas Act, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (S. 1071) to require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to disinter the remains of Fernando V. Cota from Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery, Texas, and for other purposes; and for other purposes."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on ordering the previous question on H. Res. 936, on agreeing to the resolution, if ordered, and on motion to suspend the rules and pass H.R. 3857, as amended, if ordered, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of December 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 936, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Leger Fernandez demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 936.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 936 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3898) to amend the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to make targeted reforms with respect to waters of the United States and other matters, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3383) to amend the Investment Company Act of 1940 with respect to the authority of closed-end companies to invest in private funds; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3638) to direct the Secretary of Energy to prepare periodic assessments and submit reports on the supply chain for the generation and transmission of electricity, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3628) to amend the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 to add a standard related to State consideration of reliable generation, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3668) to promote interagency coordination for reviewing certain authorizations under section 3 of the Natural Gas Act, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (S. 1071) to require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to disinter the remains of Fernando V. Cota from Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery, Texas, and for other purposes; and for other purposes."
The House resumed one minute speeches.
The House received a message from the Senate. The Senate passed S. 414 and S. 1437.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Hoyer to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of December 10.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Craig A. Goldman to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
